crypto.name: Criminal
crypto.desc:
It would be a crime for me to just give you the flag, so I'll encrypt it first before sending it. I'll even compress it to make it faster to transmit!

Note: the flag matches the regex gigem{[a-z_]+} (the curly braces are not quantifiers).

crypto.name: Emoji Group
crypto.desc: Emoji seem to have their own unique properties and strange combinations, so why not make a group out of them?

crypto.name: Jumbled
crypto.desc: The RSA Public and Private keys are provided. However, the private key seems to be jumbled in a block size of 10 hex characters. Can you get the flag?

crypto.name: PCG
crypto.desc: QCG seems a little too simple, so instead I rolled my own rng using polynomials.

crypto.name: QCG
crypto.desc: Java uses LCG for random number generation, so I rolled my own random nunber generator, QCG. Surely it is more secure than LCD.

crypto.name: Smooth Signatures
crypto.desc: I've heard signatures are pretty good tools for verifying the sender. Signatures are suposed to be personalized and unique, so surely this one is impossible to forge... right?

crypto.name: Truncated 1
crypto.desc: Only part of the private key was able to be retrieved. Decrypt the flag.txt.enc file.

crypto.name: Truncated 2
crypto.desc: It seems even less was able to be retrieved this time. Decrypt the flag.txt.enc file.

forensic.name: Corrupted
forensic.desc:
Can't seem to open the file.

The file was corrupted with operations used through this application: https://tamuctf.com/5d6b407ee061e8696136d4dfd25f24b0/static/corrupted-cc.zip

forensic.name: Deleted
forensic.desc: We found this file and was told that it contains a flag within it. Can you find the flag?

forensic.name: Fuzzy
forensic.desc:
The image.jpg file has a similar image file but not the same somewhere out of many jpg images. Can you find the similar image?

Images: https://tamuctf.com/5d6b407ee061e8696136d4dfd25f24b0/static/fuzzy-images.zip

Note: The flag is not the file name, nor is the flag embedded in the image using metadata or any steg technique.

forensic.name: SMP
forensic.desc: We'd call it Bedwars but we suck at Bedwars too much.

misc.name: Ladders
misc.desc: PLCs use ladder logic as a programming language. Where is the flag in the code?

misc.name: Lost Tourist
misc.desc:
I'm playing hide and seek with a friend, and I am the seeker. I received a hint from a friend about their whereabouts, can you find out where my friend is?

Note: flag format will be gigem{name_of_location}. Additionally, The location is where the picture was taken from.

pwn.name: Admin Panel
pwn.desc:
I made a secure login panel for administrators to access.I might not be the best C programmer out there, but just in case, I decided to enable several standard security measures to prevent unauthorized access.

NOTE: Successful exploit attempts may take several tries, due to security measures.

pwn.name: Index
pwn.desc: I added bounds checking to my array accesses, so good luck getting the flag now!

pwn.name: Janky
pwn.desc: Pwn isn't fun if your solve isn't janky.

pwn.name: Rift
pwn.desc: You get a printf! You get a printf! Everyone gets a printf!

pwn.name: Shrink
pwn.desc: The ++ in C++ means extra security, right?

rev.name: Alien
rev.desc: Run the lm3s6965 firmware. Press enter to let it know you're listening. Read the flag.

rev.name: Deflect
rev.desc:
An overworked TAMUctf dev went rogue and started leaking flags on one of our internal networks! The service was last seen online at http://10.8.0.1:1337, but we can't seem to connect to the server for some reason. We've managed to recover the server binary and some of the source code; can you figure out a way to communicate with the server?

Once you've figured it out, use the provided OpenVPN configuration file to connect to the internal network.

rev.name: Enlightenment
rev.desc: Sometimes, it's nice to just listen and observe.

rev.name: ROP
rev.desc: "rev" and "pwn" have a hamming distance of 5, so they're basically the same thing, right?

rev.name: Resistant
rev.desc: All these RE challenges are just too easy! So what happens when the binary fights back?

rev.name: Reveille Petter
rev.desc: We got this program that has our school mascot, and it promises a flag. Can you get the flag?

web.name: Cereal
web.desc: Just made a new website. It's a work in progress, please don't judge...

web.name: Forgotten Password
web.desc: We discovered that this blog owner's email is b8500763@gmail.com through reconaissance. We do not have access to the password of the account, how could we login regardless?

web.name: Remote
web.desc:
I just released the newest version of my online image repository.

Patch notes:

    Added ability to upload via URL

Note: The flag is located in /tmp/.
